unnormalised: The sun beat down on Ramlal's back as he surveyed his field in Rajasthan. Years of conventional farming had left the soil depleted, demanding ever-increasing doses of chemical fertilizers and pesticides. He remembered his grandfather, Dadu, telling stories of bountiful harvests using only cow dung and natural methods. Dadu’s words, " धरती माँ का सम्मान करो (Respect Mother Earth)," echoed in Ramlal's mind.
normalised: The sun beat down on Ramlal's back as he surveyed his field in Rajasthan. Years of conventional farming had left the soil depleted, demanding ever increasing doses of chemical fertilizers and pesticides. He remembered his grandfather, Dadu, telling stories of bountiful harvests using only cow dung and natural methods. Dadu's words, "Dharti Maa ka Samman Karo (Respect Mother Earth)," echoed in Ramlal's mind.

unnormalised: Inspired, Ramlal decided to transition to organic farming. It wasn't easy. The first year, the yield was significantly lower. His neighbour, Sharmaji, smirked, predicting Ramlal's failure. "Organic? It's a fad, Ramlal! Stick to DAP and Urea!" he'd scoff. But Ramlal persevered. He attended workshops organized by the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) and learned about composting techniques, using vermicompost, and introducing beneficial insects to control pests. He even started using 'Panchagavya,' a traditional concoction made from cow dung, cow urine, milk, curd, and ghee, as a natural fertilizer.

He attended workshops organized by the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (I C A R) and learned about composting techniques, using vermicompost, and introducing beneficial insects to control pests. He even started using 'Panchagavya,' a traditional concoction made from cow dung, cow urine, milk, curd, and ghee, as a natural fertilizer.

unnormalised: Slowly, things began to change. The soil started to regain its fertility. Earthworms reappeared, turning the soil and improving aeration. His crop, primarily wheat and mustard, began to show resilience to diseases. The taste of the produce was noticeably different – richer and more flavorful. He started selling his organic produce at a premium in the local market in Jaipur, earning Rs. 50 more per kg than conventional wheat. Word spread, and soon, he was supplying organic vegetables to a fancy restaurant in the city.

unnormalised: Dr. Patel from the Krishi Vigyan Kendra (KVK) visited Ramlal's farm and was impressed. He showcased Ramlal's success story to other farmers in the region. Ramlal became a sort of local hero, proving that organic farming could be both economically viable and environmentally sustainable.

unnormalised: He even converted a portion of his land, about 500 sq ft, into a kitchen garden, growing organic vegetables for his family. His children, who previously disliked eating vegetables, now eagerly devoured the freshly harvested tomatoes and cucumbers.
normalised: He even converted a portion of his land, about five hundred square feet, into a kitchen garden, growing organic vegetables for his family. His children, who previously disliked eating vegetables, now eagerly devoured the freshly harvested tomatoes and cucumbers.

unnormalised: Ramlal now believes that organic farming is not just a method of agriculture but a way of life – a way of respecting the land and ensuring a healthy future for generations to come. He plans to expand his organic farm, maybe even add a small dairy farm to produce his own organic fertilizer and improve his income. He smiles, remembering Dadu's words, realizing that true progress lies in harmony with nature. He hopes that more farmers in his village, even Sharmaji, will eventually embrace this sustainable path.
